section.name: Mark to Market (financial) accounting, import data from tax accounting.
section.p: Keywords: Mark To Market accounting Vs. Tax accounting, current market value, fair value, import data from tax accounting, accounting of business (trade) name.

The law (IRS) demands Bob to keep entries (in either single entry or in double entries accounting system) to estimate his taxes in calendar year period. Bob wants to estimate his real business results monthly. Market accounting (double entries system) is based on rule:
Assets - Liabilities = current market value of Bob's business (How much he can earn if he sold it right now) = Owner's equity

The most entries from Tax accounting is relevant to Market one. Excluded entries are:
Property deprecation
Closing entries (yearly)
All bad debts entries

section.h4: Evaluating market cost of a depreciable property
section.p: To report loss by market rules, Bob created account "Other losses":

If you bought something (not for resale), then you usually can't sold it for the same price. Bob thinks that he can sold his Ford right now (in January) for 20000 USD, so he reported Ford value loss (transfered the loss amount into Other losses):
* this loss is not exceed ford deprecation (that is made according to tax rules) at the end of the year, so it's taxable (business) expense.

In opposite to tax accounting rules, Bob wants to report such losses immediately. Funny coffee shop bad debt is 67.47 - 33.73 = 33.74. If IRS approve this bad debt, then Bob's income tax deducting will be roughly 33.74 * 25% = 8.44 (25 is predicted Bob's income tax rate). So he created new asset account Income Tax Deducting:
* ID for account must be a word without spaces maximum 25 letters!
Then Bob transferred 64.47 and 33.73 into it (with same way as bad debt in tax accounting), then transferred 25.30 from it into Other losses:
* to be brief, sample database bobs-pizza-market6.sqlite contains summary revenue and expenses entries instead of lot of Purchase and Sales invoices, so trial balance on 31 Jan is:
Bob made on 31 Jan closing entries into Retained Earnings account:
After that gross revenue is 9,037.10. Bob's income tax roughly is 9,037.10 * 25% = 2259.28, so Bob transferred it from Retained Earnings:
As a result the balance sheet on 31 Jan is:
So Bob earn 6,777.82USD in January(*) and his business market value is 46,777.82USD.
* take note that it is a simple example that does not include other taxes and their properly rates, also liabilities, such as taxes, must be payed.

In February Bob has sold pizza for 37,000 USD, expenses is 11,000 USD. So gross income = 26,000 USD, income tax = 6,500 USD (Bob earned 19,500 in Feb vs 6,777 in Jan). Bob closed February with result: his business market value is 66,277.82. But at this time (on Feb 29 evening) a reliable businessman called Bob and asked him that he wants to buy Bob's pizza business for 80,000 USD. Bob refused this offer and reported this event (increased business value for 13722.18) with new asset account Bob's pizza name:
Business (trade) name value always reflects to number of customers that prefer its (business maker's) goods or services.
